questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions :  THE house — the only one in the entire valley — sat on the crest of a low hill. From this height one could see the river and the field of ripe corn dotted with the flowers that always promised a good harvest. The only thing the earth needed was a downpour or at least a shower. Throughout the morning Lencho — who knew his fields intimately — had done nothing else but see the sky towards the north-east.  “Now we’re really going to get some water, woman.”  The woman who was preparing supper, replied, “Yes, God willing”. The older boys were working in the field, while the smaller ones were playing near the house until the woman called to them all, “Come for dinner”. It was during the meal that, just as Lencho had predicted, big drops of rain began to fall. In the north-east huge mountains of clouds could be seen approaching. The air was fresh and sweet. The man went out for no other reason than to have the pleasure of feeling the rain on his body, and when he returned he exclaimed, ‘‘These aren’t raindrops falling from the sky, they are new coins. The big drops are ten cent pieces and the little ones are fives.’’  With a satisfied expression he regarded the field of ripe corn with its flowers, draped in a curtain of rain. But suddenly a strong wind began to blow and along with the rain very large hailstones began to fall. These truly did resemble new silver coins. The boys, exposing themselves to the rain, ran out to collect the frozen pearls.  ‘‘It’s really getting bad now,’’ exclaimed the man. “I hope it passes quickly.” It did not pass quickly. For an hour the hail rained on the house, the garden, the hillside, the cornfield, on the whole valley. The field was white, as if covered with salt.  Not a leaf remained on the trees. The corn was totally destroyed. The flowers were gone from the plants. Lencho’s soul was filled with sadness. When the storm had passed, he stood in the middle of the field and said to his sons, “A plague of locusts would have left more than this. The hail has left nothing. This year we will have no corn.’’  That night was a sorrowful one. “All our work, for nothing.” ‘‘There’s no one who can help us.” “We’ll all go hungry this year.”  But in the hearts of all who lived in that solitary house in the middle of the valley, there was a single hope: help from God.  “Don’t be so upset, even though this seems like a total loss. Remember, no one dies of hunger.”  “That’s what they say: no one dies of hunger.”  All through the night, Lencho thought only of his one hope: the help of God, whose eyes, as he had been instructed, see everything, even what is deep in one’s conscience. Lencho was an ox of a man, working like an animal in the fields, but still he knew how to write. The following Sunday, at daybreak, he began to write a letter which he himself would carry to town and place in the mail. It was nothing less than a letter to God.

questions.question_text_1: With a satisfied expression he regarded the field of ripe corn with its flowers, draped in a curtain of rain. The word ‘draped’ means ____.
question_texts: With a satisfied expression he regarded the field of ripe corn with its flowers, draped in a curtain of rain. The word ‘draped’ means ____.

options.option_text: To conceal things that are unattractive
To conceal the evidence of one’s bad actions

When the storm had passed, he stood in the middle of the field and said to his sons, “A plague of locusts would have left more than this. The hail has left nothing. This year we will have no corn.’’  That night was a sorrowful one. “All our work, for nothing.” ‘‘There’s no one who can help us.” “We’ll all go hungry this year.”  But in the hearts of all who lived in that solitary house in the middle of the valley, there was a single hope: help from God.  “Don’t be so upset, even though this seems like a total loss. Remember, no one dies of hunger.”  “That’s what they say: no one dies of hunger.”  All through the night, Lencho thought only of his one hope: the help of God, whose eyes, as he had been instructed, see everything, even what is deep in one’s conscience. Lencho was an ox of a man, working like an animal in the fields, but still he knew how to write. The following Sunday, at daybreak, he began to write a letter which he himself would carry to town and place in the mail. It was nothing less than a letter to God.
question_texts: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions :  THE house — the only one in the entire valley — sat on the crest of a low hill. From this height one could see the river and the field of ripe corn dotted with the flowers that always promised a good harvest. The only thing the earth needed was a downpour or at least a shower. Throughout the morning Lencho — who knew his fields intimately — had done nothing else but see the sky towards the north-east.  “Now we’re really going to get some water, woman.”  The woman who was preparing supper, replied, “Yes, God willing”. The older boys were working in the field, while the smaller ones were playing near the house until the woman called to them all, “Come for dinner”. It was during the meal that, just as Lencho had predicted, big drops of rain began to fall. In the north-east huge mountains of clouds could be seen approaching. The air was fresh and sweet. The man went out for no other reason than to have the pleasure of feeling the rain on his body, and when he returned he exclaimed, ‘‘These aren’t raindrops falling from the sky, they are new coins. The big drops are ten cent pieces and the little ones are fives.’’  With a satisfied expression he regarded the field of ripe corn with its flowers, draped in a curtain of rain. But suddenly a strong wind began to blow and along with the rain very large hailstones began to fall. These truly did resemble new silver coins. The boys, exposing themselves to the rain, ran out to collect the frozen pearls.  ‘‘It’s really getting bad now,’’ exclaimed the man. “I hope it passes quickly.” It did not pass quickly. For an hour the hail rained on the house, the garden, the hillside, the cornfield, on the whole valley. The field was white, as if covered with salt.  Not a leaf remained on the trees. The corn was totally destroyed. The flowers were gone from the plants. Lencho’s soul was filled with sadness. When the storm had passed, he stood in the middle of the field and said to his sons, “A plague of locusts would have left more than this. The hail has left nothing. This year we will have no corn.’’  That night was a sorrowful one. “All our work, for nothing.” ‘‘There’s no one who can help us.” “We’ll all go hungry this year.”  But in the hearts of all who lived in that solitary house in the middle of the valley, there was a single hope: help from God.  “Don’t be so upset, even though this seems like a total loss. Remember, no one dies of hunger.”  “That’s what they say: no one dies of hunger.”  All through the night, Lencho thought only of his one hope: the help of God, whose eyes, as he had been instructed, see everything, even what is deep in one’s conscience. Lencho was an ox of a man, working like an animal in the fields, but still he knew how to write. The following Sunday, at daybreak, he began to write a letter which he himself would carry to town and place in the mail. It was nothing less than a letter to God.

props.summary:
This question paper is for **"Foundation Level: Semester 1: English 1"**, focusing on **reading comprehension, vocabulary, grammar, listening skills, and communication**. Below is a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, and principles** tested in this exam, followed by a **knowledge graph** in Mermaid syntax.

---

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts Summary**
#### **1. Reading Comprehension**
   - **Key Skills Tested**:
     - Understanding **contextual meaning** of words (e.g., "crest," "draped," "frozen").
     - Identifying **synonyms/antonyms** (e.g., "frozen" → "melted").
     - Inferring **character emotions/motivations** (e.g., Lencho’s hope for rain, despair after the hailstorm).
     - Recognizing **literary devices** (e.g., metaphors like "raindrops as coins," similes like "field white as salt").
     - **True/False questions** based on passage details (e.g., "Locusts are birds").
   - **Passage Analyzed**:
     - *"A Letter to God"* (Lencho’s story about hope, faith, and natural disasters).

#### **2. Vocabulary**
   - **Word Meanings**:
     | Word          | Meaning                                                                 |
     |---------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|
     | Crest         | Top of a hill                                                            |
     | Draped        | Covered loosely                                                          |
     | Conscience    | Inner sense of right/wrong                                               |
     | Furtive       | Secretive/stealthy                                                       |
     | Perched       | Positioned on a high place (e.g., a bird on a wire)                     |
     | Manifest      | Exhibit/display                                                          |
     | Metaphysical  | Conceptual/abstract                                                      |
   - **Idioms/Phrases**:
     | Idiom/Phrase       | Meaning                                  |
     |-------------------|------------------------------------------|
     | Pale in comparison | Less important                           |
     | On the same page   | Agreeing on something                    |
     | Cut off           | Disconnected (call)                      |
     | Breaking up       | Voice/audio distorting                   |

#### **3. Grammar**
   - **Parts of Speech**:
     - **Nouns**: Abstract (e.g., "jealousy") vs. concrete (e.g., "shoes").
     - **Verbs**: Subject-verb agreement (e.g., "They cook dinner" is correct).
     - **Tenses**:
       - Present progressive (e.g., "is happening now").
       - Past simple (e.g., "Lencho wrote a letter").
     - **Modals**: "Should" (advice), "could" (possibility).
   - **Sentence Structure**:
     - Correct usage of **"whether"** (not "whethear/weather").
     - Avoiding redundancy (e.g., "discuss ~~about~~ the matter" → "discuss the matter").
     - Comparative forms (e.g., "as naughty as").
   - **Phrasal Verbs**:
     | Phrasal Verb | Meaning                          |
     |--------------|----------------------------------|
     | Opt into     | Choose to join                   |
     | Call off     | Cancel                           |
     | Leave        | Past tense of "leave" (not "left")|

#### **4. Listening Skills** (Audio-Based Questions)
   - **Stress/Syllables**:
     - Stress patterns (e.g., **"pas**ionate" → first syllable).
     - Syllable count (e.g., "fixture" = 2, "professional" = 4).
     - Vowel sounds (e.g., "continue" → second syllable is short).
   - **Pauses in Speech**:
     - Natural pauses in sentences (e.g., commas, clauses).

#### **5. Communication (Telephone Conversations)**
   - **Professional Etiquette**:
     - Greetings: "Thank you for calling [Company]."
     - Clarifying audibility: "Am I audible to you?" / "Can you hear me?"
     - Handling disconnections: "The call was cut off."
   - **Common Phrases**:
     | Scenario               | Phrase                          |
     |------------------------|---------------------------------|
     | Network issues         | "Your voice keeps breaking up."|
     | Ending a call          | "Thanks for calling."           |

#### **6. Literary Devices & Writing**
   - **Imagery**: Sensory descriptions (e.g., "field draped in rain").
   - **Contrast**: "Once enormous, now a miserable shack."
   - **Personification**: "Shadows stared."
   - **Collocations**:
     | Adjective  | Noun       |
     |------------|------------|
     | Powerful   | Engine     |
     | Booming    | Economy    |
     | Happily    | Married    |
